author: By Jacob Bacharach
title: The Anticlimax of the Jan. 6 Hearings
description: Even if they drag a few million American eyeballs away from their streaming platforms for a night or two, the hearings could well be a dud.
content: A public examination of the apparent plotting and planning that exploded into violence on Jan. 6 ought to make for great TV; the efforts to overturn the presidential election were at turns grimly serious and darkly comic, oscillating wildly between parody and horror. But the Capitol riot hearings, which begin on Thursday, may well be a dud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: ‘The Facemaker,’ a Grisly but Inspiring Story of Surgery During World War I
description: Lindsey Fitzharris’s new book recounts the life and work of a pioneering reconstructive surgeon whose technical skill and bedside manner helped disfigured soldiers.
content: The more disembodied our digital existences become, the more startling it can be to read about medical practices from a century ago — something I was reminded of again and again while reading Lindsey Fitzharris’s grisly yet inspiring new book, “The Facemaker.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Tony Nominees for Choreography Put the Past in Motion
description: Musicals like “MJ” and “Paradise Square” take on dance of the past — with some missed opportunities. But the dance in For Colored Girls” helps us to “remember what cannot be said.”
content: A Black dancer and an Irish one face off in a dance contest in 19th-century New York. They take turns, each trying to top the other with steps and rhythms that are unique and unbeatable. It’s adversarial but also collegial, since the premise both assumes and encourages commonality, the kind of back-and-forth that breeds hybrids. This is a primal scene of American dance, and a version of it is on Broadway now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Shawn Hubler
title: 6 Takeaways From Tuesday’s Elections
description: Crime was on voters’ minds in California, and for Republican incumbents in the House, a vote for a bipartisan Jan. 6 inquiry loomed large.
content: For the most part on Tuesday, primary voters in seven states from New Jersey to California showed the limits of the ideological edges of both parties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Bradley
title: Lauren Halsey Sees the Future
description: The artist’s work looks at the storied past and present of the deeply misunderstood community of South Central Los Angeles and creates new possibilities.
content: Growing up on the east side of South Central Los Angeles, Lauren Halsey made worlds appear on her bedroom walls. She rendered her life as she saw it and as she imagined it, knowing both visions were true. For inspiration, she scavenged through the pages of magazines: her grandmother’s trove of National Geographics and her own prized collection of issues of Vibe, the magazine of Black music and culture co-founded by Quincy Jones in 1993.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Sides With Border Agent Accused of Using Excessive Force
description: In a 6-to-3 decision, the justices made it harder to sue federal officials for money in cases accusing them of violating the Constitution.
content: WASHINGTON — The owner of an inn on the Canadian border who said he had been assaulted by a Border Patrol agent may not sue the agent for violating the Constitution by using excessive force, the Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Sisson
title: Black Developers Elevate Community Needs in Major Projects
description: In multibillion-dollar projects around the nation, Black builders are investing in neighborhoods through commitments to inclusion, affordable housing and diversity hiring.
content: For decades, multibillion-dollar projects across the United States sought to create new downtown neighborhoods, often by reimagining underused assets, like defunct factories or rail yards. In recent years, a new crop of projects has offered the same expansive scope, but with leadership that mirrors the community.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Is the #MeToo Movement Dying?
description: Nearly five years later, some have concluded that the forces of backlash have won.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Wednesdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nadia Owusu
title: ‘Look What You’ve Turned Us Into’: The Roots of Women’s Shame
description: Three recent memoirs detail various injustices inflicted on young female bodies.
content: By age 11, Sara Kruzan had endured terrible abuse. Her mother was violent and used racist slurs against her (Kruzan’s mother is white, her father Black). She was first molested at 5, by her mother’s friend. Kindness from adults was rare. So, when a man in a red Mustang offered her ice cream one day, she accepted, hoping he’d save her. As she writes in I CRIED TO DREAM AGAIN: Trafficking, Murder, and Deliverance: A Memoir (200 pp., Pantheon, $27), instead that man — whom she calls G.G. — groomed, raped and trafficked her for sex for years. At 16, manipulated once more by her abusive teenage boyfriend, Kruzan shot G.G. in the back of the head, killing him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Who won and who lost in Tuesday’s primary elections.
description: The recall of San Francisco’s district attorney and the Los Angeles mayor’s race drew the most attention, but several other contests were decided, too.
content: Voters in seven states weighed in on key contests in Tuesday’s primaries. Here is a rundown of some of the most notable wins and losses:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Marriage Classes at Guantánamo
description: Learning about love from his fellow detainees gave a young Yemeni man hope.
content: Mansoor Adayfi was only 19 when he arrived at the prison camp at the Guantánamo Bay Naval Base in Cuba. Growing up in a tiny village in the mountains of Yemen, “I didn’t know much about the world,” he wrote in his Modern Love essay. “Now my world was Guantánamo.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: A Wider Lens on the MeToo Backlash: Who Pays for Societal Change?
description: The same fundamentals apply to patriarchal systems, whether in Hollywood or India: Threats to men’s status can provoke broader resistance than you might think.
content: Before I became a journalist, I spent a brief period as a commercial litigation associate, working long hours on disputes over securities, bankruptcy agreements, and contracts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: Honoring and Celebrating Juneteenth and Pride Month
description: With panels, performances and parties around New York City, June can be an opportunity to reflect and to appreciate community.
content: For many New Yorkers, June — Pride Month and home to Juneteenth — can be a time for reflection and reconnection. The month is a time to both celebrate and meditate on queer and Black culture through a variety of events.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: How Jared Kushner Washed His Hands of Donald Trump Before Jan. 6
description: Mr. Kushner’s role in the final months of the Trump White House could come into sharp relief once the committee investigating the attack on the Capitol opens hearings.
content: WASHINGTON — On Thursday, Nov. 5, 2020, barely 24 hours after President Donald J. Trump claimed in the middle of the night that “frankly, we did win this election,” Jared Kushner woke up in his Kalorama mansion and announced to his wife that it was time to leave Washington. “We’re moving to Miami,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: Sarah Silverman’s ‘Bedwetter’ Musical Has Sprung a Leak
description: The comedian’s memoir was funny. But when the new show based on it tries for something deeper, it sinks into bathos.
content: Zingy, 10-year-old Sarah Silverman (Zoe Glick) isn’t a natural fit for the town of Bedford, N.H., where sour, flinty fatalism is the norm. “May all your dreams come true,” one local says at a birthday party. “Mine did not.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Oris Buckner, Detective Who Blew Whistle on Police Abuse, Dies at 70
description: The only Black man on the New Orleans homicide squad, he provided key testimony in one of the city’s most notorious civil rights cases.
content: Oris Buckner, who as New Orleans’s only Black homicide detective in the early 1980s exposed one of the worst cases of police violence in the city’s history, leading to the conviction of three officers on civil rights charges, died on June 1 in Houston. He was 70.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Our Kids Lost Special Moments During the Pandemic. They Won’t Get Them All Back.
description: My fourth grader thinks about every event she’s missed, and I can’t pretend it doesn’t hurt.
content: Covid ran through my family in May at a languid pace: There was only one week of the past month when none of us had it, and none of our cases were concurrent. While I am incredibly grateful that we’re all vaccinated and no one had a remotely serious case, it was, of course, pretty disruptive, especially for my older daughter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Uvalde Voices Plead With Congress for Action on Gun Control
description: The parents of Lexi Rubio, a fourth grader killed at Robb Elementary School, and Uvalde’s sole pediatrician were among those demanding new gun laws at a Capitol Hill hearing.
content: WASHINGTON — Kimberly Rubio, whose 10-year-old daughter Lexi was killed during the mass shooting at Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas, pleaded with members of Congress on Wednesday to enact new gun control laws, using her own fresh pain to demand action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Mayor Eric Adams of New York City calls for federal help to fight gun violence.
description: Mr. Adams said America must decide whether it values the profits of gun manufacturers or children’s lives.
content: Mayor Eric Adams of New York City called for bipartisan gun control legislation, a ban on assault weapons and federal aid to help cities and states address the root causes of violence during testimony on Wednesday before the House Oversight Committee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Does Crypto-Mining Have a Future in New York? And What is Crypto-Mining?
description: It doesn’t involve picks and shovels, and it burns a lot of energy. Three candidates for governor also burned a lot in their first debate, with Gov. Hochul on the defensive.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll look at a bill on crypto-mining (and what crypto-mining is). We’ll also see how Gov. Kathy Hochul and her two Democratic challengers did in their first major debate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas, Ana Ionova and André Spigariol
title: Threats, Then Guns: A Journalist and an Expert Vanish in the Amazon
description: Dom Phillips, a British journalist, and Bruno Pereira, a Brazilian expert on Indigenous groups, have not been seen since Sunday. They faced threats before they disappeared.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — The Javari Valley in the Amazon rainforest is one of the most isolated places on the planet. It is a densely forested Indigenous reserve the size of Maine where there are virtually no roads, trips can take a week by boat and at least 19 Indigenous groups are believed to still live without outside contact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Villarosa
title: The Long Shadow of Eugenics in America
description: As young girls, the Relf sisters were sterilized without consent. What does the government owe them — and the thousands of other living victims?
content: I keep a sepia-tone photograph of the Relf sisters folded up and tucked in my wallet. It’s from a 1973 issue of Ebony magazine. The older of the two sisters, Minnie Lee, stares hard at the camera, her gaze direct and unsmiling but pleasant, almost quizzical. Her hair is freshly pressed, hot-curled and brushed into place, making her look older than 14. In a clean white dress with lacy zigzags, she seems ready for Sunday school. Her left arm is draped around her baby sister, Mary Alice, age 12, anchoring her in place. The younger Relf sister cracks a big, playful smile, her hair in braids — and not the usual three unruly braids from other pictures of the sisters during this time. Instead they are pinned down, neat and tidy for the Ebony shoot. The bottom of Mary Alice’s schoolgirl dress is hiked up as she reaches up to rest her right arm, the one that’s not fully formed, a disability she was born with, on her sister’s shoulder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yana Dlugy
title: Intelligence Blind Spots
description: The U.S. lacks a clear picture of Ukraine’s war strategy.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Australia’s Baby Steps Toward Severing Ties With the Queen
description: The new Labor government has established a ministerial position to begin the process of making the country a republic. But the idea is far from the top of its agenda.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — For decades, many Australians have found it a curious thing that the country’s head of state is a queen sitting on a distant English throne. Occasionally, in times of controversy, they have even batted about the idea of cutting Australia’s final monarchical ties. But more pressing issues have inevitably prevailed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Children in the Hands of God and Climate Change
description: Does the decline of religious faith influence existential anxiety about childbearing?
content: For a while, I’ve been meaning to write a column about the phenomenon of young people saying that they don’t want to have children because they fear raising them in a world laid waste by climate change. As with any idea that you keep on the shelf too long, I’ve now seen it executed by a colleague — in this case, Ezra Klein, who devoted his weekend column to arguing for an optimistic, life-affirming response to the challenges of rising temperatures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: The Meme That Derailed an Executive’s Career
description: John Demsey made diversity Estée Lauder’s corporate pitch. An Instagram post with a racial epithet cost him his job.
content: John Demsey, the beauty executive who became an industry goliath by turning MAC Cosmetics into one of Estée Lauder’s biggest subsidiaries, spent much of the first year of the pandemic in his home doing things that befit a high-flying corporate executive: Zooming with colleagues, bringing home a goldendoodle, adding to his collection of Audemars Piguets and Rolexes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: What’s Your Best, or Worst, Dining Experience of 2022?
description: Tell us what made this meal so fabulous, or a flop.
content: Dining during 2022 is a mixed bag. While it feels less fraught compared to earlier stages in the pandemic, a meal can still be a crapshoot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Karaian
title: Another quarter, another profit warning from Credit Suisse.
description: Credit Suisse has been unsettled by a number of setbacks, including billion-dollar entanglements with bankrupt lenders and hedge funds, large legal settlements and management upheaval.
content: In what is becoming a habit for Credit Suisse, the Swiss banking giant warned investors on Wednesday that it was likely to lose money in its latest quarter. This would be Credit Suisse’s third loss-making quarter in a row, each of which was preceded by a warning that the results would be worse than the bank had initially expected, as it reels from a series of crises and upheavals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Is It Finally Twilight for the Theater’s Sacred Monsters?
description: Many of the “great men” who helped America create its classics, its institutions and its own acting style were tyrants. We need to cut them loose.
content: Despotic. Agonizing. Crippling. Sadistic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Monkeypox: a Guide
description: The latest on the new outbreak.
content: Today we’re taking a break from the coronavirus pandemic to explore the other viral threat that’s grabbing headlines: monkeypox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Trader Joe’s Workers File for Election to Create Company’s First Union
description: The workers, at a store in western Massachusetts, cited health and safety concerns and cuts to benefits at the grocery chain.
content: In a sign that service industry workers continue to have a strong interest in unionizing after successful votes at Starbucks, REI and Amazon, employees at a Trader Joe’s in western Massachusetts have filed for a union election. If they win, they will create the only union at Trader Joe’s, which has more than 500 locations and 50,000 employees nationwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Gov. Hochul Is Clear Target of Democratic Rivals in Debate
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul was placed on the defensive for much of the first debate of the three Democratic candidates for governor.
content: It is hard to imagine two Democrats more ideologically divergent than Jumaane D. Williams and Thomas R. Suozzi. But for an hour Tuesday night, they set all that aside in favor of a shared mission: Shoving Gov. Kathy Hochul off an apparent glide path to a full term as governor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Parrish Art Museum Names New Director
description: Mónica Ramírez-Montagut will take over in July. The museum’s last director, Kelly Taxter, departed less than a year into the role.
content: Mónica Ramírez-Montagut, a veteran curator from Mexico, will be the new director of the Parrish Art Museum in Water Mill, N.Y., the museum announced Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘Mr. Parker’ Review: Starting Over
description: The protagonist of this new play by Michael McKeever steps gingerly out of grief’s stasis and into the unknown.
content: Being a famous artist’s spouse is not easy. Being a famous person’s surviving spouse might be even tougher. That is the plight of Terry, whose husband, Jeffrey, an artist, died as a result of a car crash. Terry, a novelist who put his own creative aspirations on hold when Jeffrey made it big, is confronting an issue many women in straight relationships have long endured: “I was defined by the man I married,” Terry says. “And now, suddenly, for the first time, I’m just … Mr. Parker. And I don’t know how to do that.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Scooters Get a Second Chance
description: Electric scooters have had their share of haters, but some cities have found ways to make them more appealing.
content: When U.S. companies started renting grown-up versions of toddlers’ plastic scooters in 2017, the mini vehicles were a lightly used and often mocked way to get around cities. But five years and one pandemic later, shared electric scooters are getting a second look and a chance to fix their bad reputation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Karen Zraick and Eduardo Medina
title: In Uvalde, a Search for Answers: How Could This Happen?
description: The shooting that left 21 people dead at an elementary school was the second such plot in four years. Residents are left grappling with the question of what could have been done to stop it.
content: UVALDE, Texas — Even as they scheduled graduation parties and made plans to move for college or start new jobs, seniors at Uvalde High School sometimes found themselves thinking back to 2018, when two of their eighth-grade classmates had been charged with plotting a mass shooting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: A New Study Points to a Surprisingly Simple Way to Ward Off Knee Pain
description: Encouraging new research suggests walking could help prevent new bouts of knee pain in people with osteoarthritis.
content: A promising new study suggests that walking could ward off knee pain for people with osteoarthritis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon and Emma Bubola
title: Angela Merkel says she ‘won’t apologize’ for her Russia diplomacy.
description: Ms. Merkel has come under fire for pushing German-Russian business interests during her tenure as chancellor.
content: Angela Merkel says she will not apologize for her policies during her 16 years as Germany’s chancellor, rebuffing criticism that they were somehow responsible for Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, in her first extensive comments to the public since leaving office last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kaitlyn Greenidge
title: The Roots of Black Pain in America
description: In “Under the Skin,” Linda Villarosa disproves once and for all the theory that people of color are responsible for their own failed health care.
content: In 1973, two Black girls, 14-year-old Minnie Lee Relf and her 12-year-old sister, Mary Alice, were forcibly taken from their home in Montgomery, Ala., and sterilized at a clinic funded by the federal government. Their parents — who had been displaced from rural Alabama into a cardboard shanty in the city and could not read or write — were tricked into agreeing to the procedure. Two years earlier, doctors had already begun to inject their oldest daughter, 15-year-old Katie, with the Depo-Provera contraceptive, then unapproved even for adult women, never mind teenagers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall and Finbarr O'Reilly
title: From the Graveside to the Front, Ukrainians Tell of Grim Endurance
description: Ukraine’s casualties in the war against Russia are a closely guarded secret. But those who have been in the trenches along the front line know how relentless the fight has become.
content: DNIPRO, Ukraine — Nearly 600 graves stretch to the edges of the military cemetery outside the city of Dnipro, marked by ranks of yellow and blue Ukrainian flags snapping in the wind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Harvey Weinstein Facing Indecent Assault Charges in Britain
description: British prosecutors said they authorized criminal charges against Mr. Weinstein for an incident in 1996.
content: The British authorities have authorized criminal charges against Harvey Weinstein on two counts of indecent assault against a woman in 1996 in London, the country’s Crown Prosecution Service announced in a news release Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Colorado to Examine Lauren Boebert’s Mileage Claims and Tax Liens
description: The state’s attorney general has referred for review a fraud complaint from the group that targeted Representative Madison Cawthorn, in a sign of trouble for the first-term congresswoman.
content: WASHINGTON — Colorado officials are examining allegations that Representative Lauren Boebert, a Republican representing the state’s western half, inflated the mileage she logged on the campaign trail in 2020 and then used more than $20,000 in reimbursements from donors to pay off years of tax liens on her restaurant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Okrent
title: Reckoning With a Pandemic, as a Doctor and a Human
description: In his essay collection “Virology,” Joseph Osmundson examines the myriad ways we coexist with viruses.
content: It’s March 16, 2020, and Joseph Osmundson is stocking up on red onions. Yesterday, public schools were shut down. The day before that, an 82-year-old woman became New York City’s first Covid death. A professor of microbiology at N.Y.U., Osmundson sees clearly that the coming months will bring many more, but at the moment he’s thinking of the past: “I often find myself mourning the voices that I wish we still had to write us through a present crisis, even in line at the grocery store.” In this, his third book, Osmundson has tried to do just that. “Virology” is composed of 11 essays whose connective tissue — parts queer theory, molecular science and social criticism — consists mostly of what Audre Lorde calls the only answer to death: “the heat and confusion of living.” The subtitle, “Essays for the Living, the Dead and the Small Things in Between,” is significant; these are essays not about but for. These are love essays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: Moderna says new trial results show that a revised vaccine works better against Omicron.
description: A significantly stronger immune response against Omicron is seen, but it remains unclear how an updated vaccine will fare against future versions of the virus.
content: Moderna released preliminary results on Wednesday on an updated coronavirus vaccine that targets the Omicron variant, calling it “our lead candidate” to serve as a U.S. booster shot in the fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: Meet Stiltgrass, Your New Garden Adversary
description: Here’s how to identify this fast-spreading invasive weed — and what to do about it, if you find it on your property.
content: Have you had the displeasure of meeting stiltgrass?

title: Satellite Imagery Shows Ukrainian Water Flowing Again to Crimea, as Russia Nears Big Objective
description: Ukraine blocked a freshwater to canal to the Crimean Peninsula after Russia occupied it 2014. Moscow has fully restored the flow, easing its path to a “land bridge” with Russia, images show.
content: Russian forces have restored a piece of Ukrainian infrastructure vital to the “land bridge” that Moscow seeks to establish linking Russian territory to the Crimean Peninsula: a canal that supplies water from southern Ukraine to the peninsula, according to satellite images and a statement on Tuesday by the Kremlin’s defense minister, Sergei K. Shoigu.

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: President of Museum of Natural History to Step Down After Nearly 30 Years
description: Ellen V. Futter, who in 1993 became the first woman to head a major New York City-based museum, will leave when the Gilder Center opens next year.
content: After an unusually long tenure of nearly 30 years as president of the American Museum of Natural History, Ellen V. Futter on Wednesday informed the board that she would step down next March, following the scheduled opening of the institution’s new Richard Gilder Center for Science, Education and Innovation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaux Laskey
title: 13 Potluck Desserts You Can Make in a 9-by-13 Pan
description: That unsung hero of the kitchen gets its star turn.
content: Hand-carved wooden spoons and millennial pink all-purpose pans may get all the attention on Instagram, but the real unsung hero of the kitchen is the 9-by-13 baking dish. They’re inexpensive, easy to transport (just cover the top with aluminum foil), and you can serve right from the dish, whether you’re sitting around a table or on a picnic blanket. They’re particularly good for desserts that serve a crowd, like sheet cakes, cobblers, brownies and bars. Just in time for summer cookouts, here are 13 of our best 9-by-13 desserts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Miah Cerrillo, 11, who hid from the Uvalde gunman, says students must ‘have security.’
description: She also described the attack to lawmakers, including watching the gunman shoot her friend and then smearing blood on herself to appear dead.
content: Miah Cerrillo, a fourth-grade student in Uvalde, Texas, who smeared a dead classmate’s blood on herself to avoid being targeted by the gunman who killed 19 students and two teachers in her classroom, described the nightmarish attack in a video played before members of Congress on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Jesus Jiménez
title: Armed Man Traveled to Justice Kavanaugh’s Home to Kill Him, Officials Say
description: The man, Nicholas John Roske, 26, said he was upset about the shooting in Uvalde, Texas, and impending decisions on abortion and guns, a federal affidavit says.
content: A man armed with a pistol, a knife and other weapons was arrested near the Maryland home of Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh early Wednesday after he said he traveled from California to kill the Supreme Court justice, federal officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Five Influences on the Horror Film ‘Watcher’
description: Chloe Okuno’s bone-chilling debut feature is about a woman unnerved by a man watching her from an apartment window. The director shares what was in her head while assembling it.
content: I recently watched “Watcher,” the nerve-plucking new horror film from Chloe Okuno, inside a vaudeville-era movie palace during the Cleveland International Film Festival. source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beth Harpaz
title: Travelers Ask, Cash, What’s That?
description: In a transition hastened by the pandemic, increasingly you can travel abroad and barely ever handle a physical bill or coin, whether pounds, kroner or euros. A guide to going cashless overseas.
content: On a recent trip to England, Andrew Dodson, 35, and his wife, Erin, 32, who live in Traverse City, Mich., had an unexpected problem: No matter how hard they tried, they couldn’t spend the 700 British pounds they’d brought along.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Progressive groups and medical organizations have adopted inclusive language, which has led to terms like “pregnant people” and “chestfeeding.”
content: The American Civil Liberties Union, whose advocacy on reproductive rights is of more than a half-century vintage, recently tweeted its alarm about the precarious state of legal abortion:

title: ‘Most Violence Is Not Caused by Mental Illness’

content: The George W. Bush Presidential Center, in Dallas, is a 226,000-square-foot building that houses the George W. Bush Presidential Library and Museum and the George W. Bush Institute. It isn’t the sort of place you go for unvarnished truth about George W. Bush. Like many institutions of its ilk, it serves up carefully curated hagiography, amid stately colonnades and a burbling fountain. Visitors enter into a 67-foot-tall atrium called Freedom Hall; the Defending Freedom Table is a large touch-screen where museumgoers can view maps and photographs from the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq. There’s a statue of Bush and his father gazing purposefully into the middle distance, and a statue of Barney and Miss Beazley, George and Laura Bush’s Scottish terriers, striking a similar pose. In the library, scholars can pore through official White House documents to extract fuller, less flattering stories of the Bush years. But the public-facing image is a portrait in whitewash. On the library’s website, an online exhibit about the Sept. 11 attacks and their aftermath hails Bush for demonstrating “the strength of American resolve.”

description: Moscow is trying to deepen its hold on occupied Ukrainian territory in the south.
content: Russia’s defense minister, Sergei Shoigu, said its military had repaired about 750 miles of railroad track in southeastern Ukraine to secure a “land bridge” from Russia through Ukraine’s eastern Donbas region, to occupied territory in Kherson and on to the Crimean Peninsula.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Two new versions of Omicron are gaining ground in the U.S., according to C.D.C. estimates.
description: The spread of the subvariants adds more uncertainty to the trajectory of the pandemic in the United States.
content: The Omicron subvariants known as BA.4 and BA.5 now represent 13 percent of new coronavirus cases in the United States, up from 7.5 percent a week ago and 1 percent in early May, according to new estimates from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: How South Dakota Voters Won a Power Struggle With G.O.P. Legislators
description: The state roundly rejected a proposal, meant to block Medicaid expansion, that would have reduced voters’ ability to direct policy. It was just the latest clash between voters and state legislatures.
content: Coming on the same night that voters in San Francisco ousted their lightning rod of a district attorney, Chesa Boudin — in what was widely interpreted as a setback for progressive ideas on criminal justice — it would have been easy to overlook what happened on Tuesday in South Dakota.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Hess
title: ‘We Took a Chonce,’ and Other Dispatches From Fandom
description: In defense of One Direction, Twitter teens and screaming women everywhere.
content: One Direction was a British boy band that was cynically assembled for the reality television competition “The X Factor” in 2010, and went on to release five albums of catchy if unremarkable pop songs before going on indefinite hiatus in 2016. (For reasons that are somewhat mysterious even to myself, I love the band.) As the internet culture reporter Kaitlyn Tiffany charts in “Everything I Need I Get From You: How Fangirls Created the Internet as We Know It,” the band’s cultural impact might have been unexceptional were it not for its fans, who built a bizarrely powerful online community featuring subversive fan-fiction narratives, absurdly funny memes and occasionally distressing coordinated campaigns that grew so influential they managed to destabilize “1D” itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora, Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Anton Troianovski and Michael Levenson
title: Russia Is Racing to Cement Its Control in Southern Ukraine
description: The Kremlin says it has rebuilt rail and road links to Crimea, while appointing proxy officials in an effort to create facts on the ground.
content: Even as Russia hammers eastern Ukraine with heavy artillery, it is cementing its grip on the south, claiming to have restored roads, rails and a critical freshwater canal that could help it claim permanent dominion over the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: U.S. Lacks a Clear Picture of Ukraine’s War Strategy, Officials Say
description: Intelligence agencies know far more about Russia’s military, even as the United States ships billions of dollars in weapons to the Ukrainians.
content: WASHINGTON — President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine has provided near-daily updates of Russia’s invasion on social media; viral video posts have shown the effectiveness of Western weapons in the hands of Ukrainian forces; and the Pentagon has regularly held briefings on developments in the war.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 8, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, June 8, 2022.
content: An item in the Conversation feature on Friday misstated the number of generations of royals standing beside Queen Elizabeth II at the Platinum Jubilee. Three generations stood by her, not four.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Military Plane Carrying 5 Marines Crashes in California, Officials Say
description: It was not immediately clear how many survived the crash, an official said. The plane, an MV-22B Osprey that belonged to the 3rd Marine Aircraft Wing, crashed in a remote area 100 miles east of San Diego.
content: A military aircraft carrying five U.S. Marines crashed in Southern California on Wednesday, according to a spokesman for the U.S. Marine Corps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘Come From Away’ to Close, the Latest Broadway Show to End Run
description: The musical, which opened in 2017, is the third to announce a closing in two days, as many shows struggle in a pandemic-softened marketplace.
content: “Come From Away,” the inspirational musical about a remote Canadian community that rallied to support thousands of stranded air travelers after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, will end its run on Broadway in October.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Lange
title: Get In. We’re Going to Save the Mall.
description: Shopping malls across the country are closing. But the mall was designed for change.
content: It is easy to think of indoor and even outdoor malls as anti-landscape: big asphalt parking lots, blank walls, artificial lighting, manufactured scents, digital sounds. But the origin of mall architecture was in the European 19th-century conservatory, where cast-iron and glass roofs covered expensive, nonnative plants. Early mall innovators like Victor Gruen emphasized the year-round good weather of indoor shopping, and leading landscape architects like Lawrence Halprin made sure the plantings were as up-to-date as the goods for sale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: The Tribeca Festival Returns in Full Bloom
description: The springtime extravaganza returns with another sweeping bill of fare. We trawled through the slate so you can savor the gems.
content: Spring in New York City is a season of promise. It’s terrific timing for the Tribeca Festival, which runs from June 8-19 and features its trademark community focus and sweeping bill of fare. Like visitors to a botanic garden, Tribeca audiences seem as keen on roaming through thickets of mainstream movies (not to mention immersive installations, TV series and scripted podcasts) as they do savoring the small films blooming alongside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs and Rachel Sherman
title: Amar Ramasar Leaves City Ballet, but Plans to Keep Balanchine Close
description: The ballet star discusses what’s next in his first interview since he won his job with the company back after a nude photo sharing scandal.
content: The dancer Amar Ramasar parted ways with New York City Ballet last month — this time on his own terms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Mark Ronchetti, a former TV meteorologist, is Republicans’ pick for New Mexico governor.
description: Mr. Ronchetti will challenge Gov. Michelle Lujan Grisham, a Democrat, in the general election.
content: Mark Ronchetti, a former Albuquerque television meteorologist, has won New Mexico’s Republican nomination for governor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Saul Griffith
title: Installing Rooftop Solar Can Be a Breeze. Just Look at Australia.
description: America’s solar power failures are mostly regulatory. That can be fixed.
content: WOLLONGONG, Australia — I recently moved back here to my home country partly because I believe Australians can show the world how much money households can save through simple climate solutions like rooftop solar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The U.S. Tech Sector Is Looking Weak. That’s a Geopolitical Risk.
description: Do we need to produce more of our own advanced technologies?
content: In a world at peace, making potato chips is just as good for a nation as making computer chips, and making movies about fighter jets is just as good as making actual fighter jets. All that matters in free trade is how much money a country earns from its efforts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze and Melissa Eddy
title: Car Plows Into a School Group in Berlin, Killing 1 and Injuring 14
description: A teacher was killed and those hurt were students traveling with her. The driver was described as “mentally impaired,” and police are investigating whether the crash was intentional.
content: BERLIN — A car plowed into a crowd of people on a busy Berlin sidewalk on Wednesday, killing a female teacher on a school trip and injuring 14 teenage students traveling with her, before crashing into the window of a store near the site of a devastating 2016 terrorist attack, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Washington
title: A Foolproof Recipe for Korokke
description: There are endless ways to make these fried Japanese delights your own.
content: There are dishes we cook, and then there are dishes we cook toward. These are the meals that follow us in memory — sometimes annoyingly, sometimes enticingly — after we’ve washed the dishes, or the next morning over coffee, a quick flickering before we’re battered by the day. These recipes expand and contract, growing right beside us. They’re like the idea of home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: Fraud and Identity Theft Trial to Test American Anti-Hacking Law
description: A woman is accused of downloading data of more than 100 million Capital One customers. Her lawyers argue a conviction would criminalize legitimate research practices.
content: Nearly three years after the disclosure of one of the largest data breaches in the United States, the former Amazon employee accused of stealing customers’ personal information from Capital One is standing trial in a case that will test the power of American anti-hacking law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Wartik and Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Dave Smith, Whose Synthesizers Shaped Electronic Music, Dies at 72
description: His innovations included the first polyphonic, programmable synthesizer and the universal connectivity of MIDI.
content: Dave Smith, a groundbreaking synthesizer designer, died on May 31 in Detroit. He was 72.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Jurassic World Dominion’ Review: Extinction Rebellion
description: Things get very hectic in the last episode of this trilogy, which brings back familiar faces (Jeff Goldblum, Laura Dern, Sam Neill) along with the usual dinosaurs.
content: “Jurassic World Dominion” starts with a nod to “The Deadliest Catch”: A marine reptile snacks on king crabs in the Bering Sea before turning its jaws on a trawler and its crew. Yikes! Then a mock newscast swiftly brings us up-to-date on the global catastrophe that began to unfold almost 30 years ago in the first “Jurassic Park” movie. In case you need a refresher, how it started was with Richard Attenborough rhapsodizing about the wonders of life; how it’s going is that the big lizards are everywhere, generally bringing out the worst in people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Catie Edmondson
title: As Survivors Demand Action, House Passes Gun Bill Doomed in the Senate
description: On a day of wrenching testimony from victims of the school shooting in Uvalde, Democrats pushed through a gun control package facing solid G.O.P. opposition and no path in the Senate.
content: WASHINGTON — The House on Wednesday voted nearly along party lines to bar the sale of semiautomatic weapons to people under the age of 21 and ban the sale of large-capacity magazines, acting as traumatized parents of victims and survivors of mass shootings made wrenching appeals for Congress to act on gun violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Aid Stalled, White House to Shift Testing Funds to Vaccines and Treatments
description: The Biden administration has warned for months that without congressional action, it could have to unwind or sacrifice key pieces of the pandemic response.
content: WASHINGTON — White House officials said on Wednesday that they would have to repurpose federal Covid-19 funds meant for coronavirus tests and protective equipment in order to supply more antiviral pills and vaccines, after so far failing to persuade Congress to pass a new pandemic relief package.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: For Franck’s 200th, an Organist Pays Grand Tribute
description: Paul Jacobs has completed his survey of the major solo organ works of César Franck, whose birthday year is passing with scattered observances.
content: It has not been the happiest 200th birthday year for César Franck. “What Happened to One of Classical Music’s Most Popular Pieces?” this newspaper asked a few months ago — the headline to an account of how Franck’s Symphony in D minor, once a standard, largely vanished from concert programs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Trump Set to Be Questioned Under Oath by New York A.G. Next Month
description: The questioning of Mr. Trump and two of his adult children as part of the attorney general’s civil investigation will begin July 15 unless New York’s highest court decides to intercede in the case.
content: Donald J. Trump and two of his adult children have agreed to be questioned under oath in mid-July by lawyers from the New York State attorney general’s office, unless the state’s highest court intervenes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: Voters in San Francisco topple the city’s progressive district attorney, Chesa Boudin.
description: Mr. Boudin, who had eliminated cash bail and sought to reduce the prison population, was removed in a vote that is set to reverberate through Democratic politics across the country.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Voters in San Francisco on Tuesday put an end to one of the country’s most pioneering experiments in criminal justice reform, ousting a district attorney who eliminated cash bail, vowed to hold police accountable and worked to reduce the number of people sent to prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Global economic woes.
content: Britain is staring down the specter of stagflation, a ruinous mix of stagnant economic growth and rapid inflation. The country is experiencing the fastest pace in consumer price growth in four decades — a 9 percent inflation rate. Economic growth ground to a halt in February and contracted slightly in March.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: Rick Caruso and Karen Bass head to a runoff in the Los Angeles mayor’s race.
description: Mr. Caruso, a billionaire developer who recently left the Republican Party to become a Democrat, will face off against Ms. Bass, a liberal congresswoman, to lead the nation’s second-largest city.
content: LOS ANGELES — Rick Caruso, a billionaire real estate developer, and Representative Karen Bass are heading to a November runoff election to become mayor of Los Angeles, in a race that has focused on voters’ worries about public safety and homelessness in the nation’s second-largest city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich
title: ‘Kimono Style’: A Beautiful Painting You Can Wear
description: Japan’s T-shaped unisex garment cut from a single bolt of silk isn’t a symbol or a relic. At the Met, it’s the vibrant feature of an international fashion conversation.
content: I’d always suspected as much, but the exhibition “Kimono Style: The John C. Weber Collection” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art has confirmed it for me: The kimono is one of the pre-eminent artistic mediums of the 20th century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Denver Broncos Pick Walton-Penner Family in Auction to Sell Team
description: The Walton-Penner group was selected from among more than a dozen bidders for the N.F.L. team, which is expected to sell for $4.65 billion, a record price.
content: The Denver Broncos have reached a tentative agreement to sell the team to Rob Walton and members of the Walton and Penner families, all but ending an auction that is expected to fetch a record $4.65 billion, more than twice the price of the previous record for an N.F.L. franchise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Todd and Julie Chrisley, Self-Made Moguls on Reality TV, Are Convicted of Fraud
description: The couple, who star on the popular show “Chrisley Knows Best,” used money from fraudulently obtained loans on luxury cars, designer clothes, real estate and travel, the Department of Justice said.
content: Todd and Julie Chrisley, the stars of “Chrisley Knows Best,” a reality TV show in which the couple project themselves as real estate moguls who judge PG-rated family squabbles according to strict standards for comportment, were convicted on Tuesday of conspiring to defraud banks out of $30 million and avoiding years of tax bills, the Department of Justice said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Grace Ashford
title: Crime, Football and the N.R.A.: Takeaways From the N.Y. Governor Debate
description: The Democratic rivals of Gov. Kathy Hochul sought to attack her on varied issues, from the funding of a Buffalo Bills stadium to a decade-old endorsement from the N.R.A.
content: Gov. Kathy Hochul took center stage on Tuesday night, finally facing her Democratic challengers in a debate that mostly played out as expected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Harvey Araton
title: These Are Not Larry Bird’s Celtics. And That’s Just Fine.
description: Trips down memory lane have grown harder as Celtics greats pass away. But the new generation is carving a memorable path of its own.
content: When Bill Walton revived and concluded his N.B.A. career with the Boston Celtics, he devised a plan on game nights to beat the city’s notoriously gridlocked traffic: He rode the subway to work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: Harvard’s President Will Step Down Next Year
description: Lawrence S. Bacow steered the university through the pandemic as well as an attack on its admissions policies, which are likely to face a Supreme Court test this year.
content: Lawrence S. Bacow announced on Wednesday that he would step down as president of Harvard in June 2023 following a tenure of five years, a period in which he steered the university through the coronavirus pandemic as well as an attack on its admissions policies, which are likely to face a Supreme Court test this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Bryson DeChambeau and Patrick Reed Set to Join Saudi-Backed LIV Golf Tour
description: As recently as last week, DeChambeau denied being enticed by the massive payouts and appearance fees being offered to the world’s top golfers by the rival league.
content: Bryson DeChambeau, the 2020 U.S. Open champion, and Patrick Reed, who won the 2018 Masters, are planning to join the new Saudi-backed LIV Golf circuit that hopes to challenge the established PGA Tour, according to multiple reports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: How Safe Are Systems Like Tesla’s Autopilot? No One Knows.
description: Automakers and technology companies say they are making driving safer, but verifying these claims is difficult.
content: Every three months, Tesla publishes a safety report that provides the number of miles between crashes when drivers use the company’s driver-assistance system, Autopilot, and the number of miles between crashes when they do not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Early Tastes of Summer
description: Hetty Mckinnon’s crispy gnocchi with tomatoes and red onion conjures late August.
content: Good morning. Summer may not start until the 21st, but I’m cooking as if it were the high season already: grilled proteins and spicy sauces; slaws everywhere; steamed clams as often as I can manage. I can’t wait to bring Hetty McKinnon’s new recipe for crispy gnocchi with tomatoes and red onion (above) into the mix, a dish inspired by Tuscan panzanella, with the gnocchi taking the place of the traditional stale bread. It’s heavy foreshadowing, a taste of August in June.
source.name: The New York Times
